div1.p: [Kean] questions Birmingham about the organization of the Ambulance Corps in France.

div1.head: Letter from [Jefferson Randolph Kean] to Henry P. Birmingham, August 29, 1917
div1.opener:

Office, U. S. A. Ambulance Service with French Army
FRANCE - 29th August 1917
Colonel Henry P. Birmingham, M.C., USA
Office of the Surgeon General
War Department, Washington
My dear Birmingham:
div1.p:
I sent in a few days ago a letter to the Surgeon General giving an account of
conditions in the ambulance service over here. I am sure that he has handed this
to you to read. If he has not done so you can doubtless find it on file as it
was really an official letter although personal in form. If you can't get it
from the files ask him to let you read it.

I am daily embarrassed by the fact that we have over here more sections than the
40 which were set aside for France; and everybody here, including the French,
is opposed to breaking up any of these sections, which have a strong esprit de
corps and have done excellent service. I hope it can be arranged that we can
be credited with at least 5 more sections. I am sure that 5 of the sections
recently organized at Allentown would not object to being sent over here with
the understanding that they would be disbanded and the personnel used to fill
up sections already at the front. They are so anxious to see active service
that they would be willing to pay this price for it, I believe.

Percy Jones, who has joined me, is not sure whether they organized more than 118
sections at Allentown. If not, 2 sections could be creditalto us and 3 sent over
to be disbanded.

There are in connection with these sections a number of very good candidates for
officers -- men who have not only had a number of months of active service at the
front and who can speak French, but who have also taken the course at the French
school of transportation at Meaux and have acquired in this way an accurate all-
round knowledge of French transport administration. It is my idea as soon as
the Chief Surgeon needs additional doctors to have the medical officers now with
the sections transferred and replaced by those trained men. This is in accord-
ance with what the Surgeon General told me was his desire, before I left, and
what he has written me since I left.

The French military authorities have requested that the enlistment of the sections
and their transfer to the United States Army Ambulance Service be made without
interruption to their duties at the front; so I have sent out a recruiting party
which will visit them at their 40-odd stations along the line and bring them
into the service there. One trouble will be that they will be already in before
we have any officers for them, as the officers of these sections will have to be
commissioned from Washington. I hope that they will be able to accept their
commissions by cable and that the delay will not be too long in getting them
through. You will see the embarrassment of having the sections enlisted before
the officers are commissioned and I hope will use your good offices in hastening
through the list. I am going to recommend for commissions only those men who

have the approval of both the heads of their own services and of the French
military authorities, who you know have a Lieutenant on duty with each section
and who thus have quite accurate knowledge of the efficiency of the men who
have been acting as officers of the sections under the volunteer system.

I have not yet been able to establish an office, but have been camping out in
two little rooms which Bradley has been good enough to place at my disposal.
It is a great pleasure to be with him and Ireland and Winter, and to see so many
other officers of our corps and of the regular service. This will, however, be
broken up at the end of the week, as General Pershing will take his headquarters
into the field to join his troops. Winter, who is as you know Chief Surgeon of
the line of communications, will probably go with General Blatchford, commanding
the line of communications, to Tours or some other point southwest of Paris and
nearer the coast. I will, therefore, in the near future probably lose all of my
old friends. Percy Jones will, however, be a great comfort, and without his
accurate and ready knowledge of the details of company administration I do not
know how I would ever be able to organize these sections as self-contained units
and got them supplied.

We are trying to get hold of some barracks, in some small town not too far from
Paris, so as to be able to bring the sections up here and organize a base camp.

Bradley says that nobody ever writes to him from the office and he rarely gets an
answer to his letters. I hope that you are not going to let me suffer from the
same dearth although. I know well how full the days are for all of you at the
office.

Please see to it that no appointments are made in Washington for any of the
sections in France who are to serve with the French troops. The French authori-
ities are most anxious that all vacancies shall be filled by men who have been
trained by actual experience at the front. Ability to speak French is a very
important qualification for the officers of this service.

Ireland and Bradley send their love. Bradley says that he has your letter in his
basket of unfinished business and will write to you very soon. I hope that you
found no difficulty in delivering the cable message which I sent from Bordeaux
to Martha. I was sure that you could find her through Ada. I suppose that Gold-
thwait has come back from England by this time and hope that you gave him my
regards, which I left at the Surgeon General's Office for him.
With best wishes and regards to all my friends in the Office, I am, always,
